tn.text: Nahum continues describing the destruction of Nineveh in poetry that began in [[:en:bible:notes:nam:01:01|1:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: The one who will dash you to pieces
tn.text: The picture is of someone breaking a pot. Alternate translation: "He who will destroy you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]).
The person who is "the one" is not clear, so translate using a general term: "Someone who will break you to pieces."

tn.ref: Man the city walls, guard the roads, make yourselves strong, assemble your armies.
tn.text: prepare for war
"Set guards on the walls for protection"

tn.ref: For Yahweh is restoring the majesty of Jacob, like the majesty of Israel
tn.text: This means that Yahweh will make Jacob and Israel great, and people will admire them again.
people who steal things by force, usually in war
destroyed everything
The nation is spoken here as if it were a cultivated grapevine. AT: "and uprooted your nation as if it were a vineyard." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]).
the soldiers of the one "who will dash" Nineveh "to pieces" ([[:en:bible:notes:nam:02:01|2:1]]).
a type of tree whose wood is good for weapons (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: The chariots speed through the streets
tn.text: "The chariot drivers drive crazily in the streets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the brightness of the chariots as they reflect the light from the sun. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Translate this the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:nam:02:01|2:1]].
Possible meaning: 1) "summons his officers" or 2) "thinks of his officers"
the soldiers who will attack Nineveh
"as they march"

This name probably is either the name of Assyria's queen or the name of an Assyrian idol. If it refers to the queen, then the passage means that the attacking soldiers stripped her of her clothes in order to humiliate her. If it refers to an idol, then the passage means that the attackers stripped the gold and silver off the image.

tn.ref: her female servants moan like doves
tn.text: "the female servants of the queen sound like doves as they moan" to mourn her loss of power (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Things stolen by force, usually in war.

tn.ref: there is no end to it
tn.text: This is a way to say there is a huge amount of something. Alternate translation: "there is a huge amount of it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: splendor of all Nineveh's beautiful things
tn.text: Possible meanings: 1) "abundance of all the beautiful things" or 2) "amount of all the beautiful things"
"All the people lose their courage" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Nineveh is being compared to a lion's den because it is a place where killers live and a place where they bring back what they have stolen from the people they have killed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"choked." Lions bite their victims' throats to prevent them from breathing.

tn.ref: filled his cave with victims, his dens with torn carcasses
tn.text: These two phrases are saying the same thing in different ways. A lion's den, its hiding place, is often in a cave. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"Understand this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the sword will devour your young lions.
tn.text: "your soldiers will die violent deaths" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"soldiers with swords" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"eat all of"
"your best young men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will cut off your plunder from your land
tn.text: The word "plunder" refers to the wealth that Nineveh captured and brought from other lands. This means that Yahweh will destroy Nineveh's ability to steal from other nations.
